document.title: Pennsylvania Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content

7CF3E752E68741CEA8DE6EDF1E4718D7.description: Provide a concluding section that follows from and supports the analysis presented.

1C1A22B257F946E1AB8674561F75D4DF.description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

DD49C7797E4E4E30B78C263A8011772E.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic and/or convey the experience and events.

C1FC1FB8907E4A24892896BF1ED83E07.description: Use appropriate and varied transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.

3E1772F05AFE42DBB8E3E5BB7DA58C25.description: Develop the analysis using relevant evidence from text(s) to support claims, opinions, ideas, and inferences and demonstrating an understanding of the text(s).

31AB0EDCDCD84CE0A67F112DA98E0F5C.description: Introduce text(s) for the intended audience, state an opinion and/or topic, establish a situation, and create an organizational structure in which ideas are logically grouped to support the writer’s purpose.

3A4A310F49BE428383EA0D6112402169.description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and/or research.

8FD2559ECBCB445E8171B8428F198ED5.description: Choose words and phrases for effect.*

3A5D6078B77941379547F1262B5EA022.description: Maintain consistency in style and tone.*

D8B76CEF23FD4A4DA4A3AE9E520654CD.description: Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.*

2A05E01A457D48E7A23301E850059EB7.description: Choose language that expresses ideas precisely and concisely, recognizing and eliminating wordiness and redundancy.*

3D92A9BCF5F84FA1822135A124EF42F5.description: Use verbs in the active and passive voice and in the conditional and subjunctive mood to achieve particular effects (e.g., emphasizing the actor or the action, expressing uncertainty, or describing a state contrary to fact).

D2777AA5C815480E9AC4B333D1B728B5.description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions.

7ADDC9F6181747238FA828521C0534BA.description: Use punctuation to separate items in a series.*

D6440851673E42F58E7EA9C18C35D71A.description: Use punctuation (i.e., commas, parentheses, and dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements.*

414784BC559440468D35EF5A5F3EB266.description: Use an ellipsis to indicate an omission.

DF852CDB9CCF438B888E9E4EA4349A21.description: Use punctuation (i.e., comma, ellipsis, and dash) to indicate a pause or break.

2EBAC41BBEA4458BBBD6EB95A44D4A1F.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling.

2320BA8C8B974041A1FD48EFEA4F401F.description: Correctly use frequently confused words (e.g., to, too, two; there, their, they’re).*

29C6A773329D464BBC00503063028616.description: Produce complete sentences, recognizing and correcting inappropriate fragments and run-on sentences.*

8BCB8AFA972A48669232D0B9FD49AA3C.description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.*

5195FED3BCF94F4086B6E3EEDCF67253.description: Recognize and correct vague pronouns (i.e., ones with unclear or ambiguous antecedents).*

0459D72FE02F478680438834B8793678.description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in pronoun number and person.*

8D7D18617CDF4053BA8F08AB97D12220.description: Place phrases and clauses within a sentence, recognizing and correcting misplaced and dangling modifiers.*

F5A60724BA0B4BBBA84846D657D17A84.description:
Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb
voice and mood.*

6B66370B236E4A5B98C5EB4854285747.description:
Form and use verbs in the indicative, imperative,
interrogative, conditional, and subjunctive mood.

3984579B75C848199715B73DA0D68972.description: Form and use verbs in the active and passive voice.

DAA59CFDA63648E5A490224DC37CE343.description: Explain the function of verbals (i.e., gerunds, participles, and infinitives) in general and their function in particular sentences.

9060AA26C3D149C798A32E3E5596EEBE.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage.

5D0F8224629F42F584C76647B166156E.description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on the narrated experiences or events.

2967E522C0BD4CEB9DD6D3042C73C7C5.description: Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to capture the action and convey experiences and events.

2DFC6D3E37524573988A383705AA125F.description: Use a variety of transitional words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence, to signal shifts from one time frame or setting to another, and to show the relationships among experiences and events.

78ACE953A1F54018B1210D2C0A6CFF3A.description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, and reflection, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

376A63E9B1FF469B92CC273EC51DD116.description: Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and point of view and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically to support the writer’s purpose.

06C0E899B33947FA95105CB78CB599A3.description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective techniques, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

AC6ADC4B965D4923A9F31007842613D5.description:
Provide a concluding section that follows from and
supports the information or explanation presented.

32BB496B89704756B1E6FBAFD8488793.description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

31B37DD164DB476FB3533C6C16230631.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

F8BD841973974FA4AD80752074AC85C5.description: Use appropriate and varied transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.

7979C05B7010433FBA16D18D21E75951.description: Develop the topic with relevant, well-chosen facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.

2B053D93F7EA4C459BF325CD7BE39089.description: Introduce a topic for the intended audience and preview what is to follow; organize ideas, concepts, and information using strategies such as definition, classification, compare/contrast, and cause/effect to support the writer’s purpose.

357A8B2D558C4E3F8B75244327E05AE6.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.

79D79EF9A3AF4F6D92F9F4B8A5C87B1D.description:
Provide a concluding section that reinforces the
claims and reasons presented.

FA8F967F09C645AC990AF7BD27AC445B.description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

90B5BD9652884146915553D0AF62A7E9.description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

AFBF54F86E714AB186B9C60C5E569A8E.description: Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and relevant evidence, using accurate, credible sources and demonstrating an understanding of the topic or text.

00C84CE9818344058112316779F41645.description: Introduce claim(s) for the intended audience, acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and support the writer’s purpose by logically organizing reasons and evidence.

8BE9BA34C1FE4A008E6404168A7626EE.description: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.

B2F814F686574312B4995CF0B509DE77.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
a. Interpret figures of speech (e.g., verbal irony, puns) in context.
b. Use the relationship between particular words to better understand each of the words.
c. Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., bullheaded, willful, firm, persistent, resolute).

70B4D5782E1B40EEAF4466FA45A1A864.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
a. Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph, a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
b. Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., precede, recede, secede).
c. Determine the meaning of technical words and phrases used in a text.

E47C61943532485E924D5814EE826A26.description: Demonstrate understanding of vocabulary and figurative language in informational texts.

41C4C30AAD484B71B985A6F24D18EA8F.description: Analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic, and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.

21FDC4D5B0A14A61B153AD16F0DE4A3C.description: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

DC6BFF1200104815844F1AFCA3493065.description: Demonstrate understanding of connections within, between, and/or among informational texts.

C4398809FE774838BE6988709B57201B.description: Determine how the author uses the meaning of words or phrases, including figurative, connotative, or technical meanings, in a text; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

75AD8C98E5A046B2A3ECC3D8E02C7875.description: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.

2D2CBC7E802D4C5C8625A4638BC4CE60.description: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.

A43A43B66E114DBE9E7D9F0301612715.description: Demonstrate understanding of craft and structure in informational texts.

27CD564033BE4350B50A9FFEA494391F.description: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, categories).

92E1924E4E5E474884654A7F5AD9F1A3.description: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.

481A43EFBD004B7E9EE4A04FDFB14F70.description: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences, conclusions, and/or generalizations drawn from the text.

AA29FEEC9EA94BB6AE7959F7EE2F9861.description: Demonstrate understanding of key ideas and details in informational texts.

C38F89FB68E74D9083854943A8DB32D7.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
a. Interpret figures of speech (e.g., verbal irony, puns) in context.
b. Use the relationship between particular words to better understand each of the words.
c. Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., bullheaded, willful, firm, persistent, resolute).

81DDC64EC1C343F5A77C4A7ADC021C1F.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
a. Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph, a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
b. Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., precede, recede, secede).

CA48534C36B44C60B10C27108AC8ED52.description: Demonstrate understanding of vocabulary and figurative language in literature.

439BE136B77440AC8DDC1B0C5BE393A8.description: Analyze how a modern work of fiction draws on themes, patterns of events, or character types from myths and traditional stories, including describing how the material is rendered new.

C81918B29BFD4464814893F16C61C27E.description: Demonstrate understanding of connections within, between, and/or among texts.

0D05C9AE22FF4C53AABBA4FD6B245B78.description: Determine how the author uses the meaning of words or phrases, including figurative and connotative meanings, in a text; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

4F5B65D3AC0B46FEBBABDA193DA75594.description: Compare and contrast the structure of two or more texts, and analyze how the differing structure of each text contributes to its meaning and style.

A20F5DAE3F574333B551C2FD5957C494.description: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.

A01F20D3C5A84F1C880821D371B89C68.description: Demonstrate understanding of craft and structure in literature.

93E089CD40664F1DA15A55047B22C28F.description: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story, drama, or poem propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.

B10041E79BC44375A89B6D9808476E75.description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.

205D10DBF67240F58805073ABF8EC7F9.description: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences, conclusions, and/or generalizations drawn from the text.

47C43767161842808FD449E165D5987B.description: Demonstrate understanding of key ideas and details in literature.
